title: Leviathan Mine
text:
Leviathan Mine is a United States <a href="superfund">superfund</a> site (<a href="List%20of%20Superfund%20sites%20in%20California">CERCLIS ID</a>: CAD98067685) at an abandoned <a href="open-pit%20mining">open-pit</a> <a href="sulfur">sulfur</a> <a href="mining">mine</a> located in <a href="Alpine%20County%2C%20California">Alpine County, California</a>. The mine is located on the eastern slope of the <a href="Sierra%20Nevada%20%28U.S.%29">Sierra Nevada</a> at about elevation, east of <a href="Markleeville">Markleeville</a> and southeast of <a href="Lake%20Tahoe">Lake Tahoe</a>. The mine site comprises approximately of land surrounded by the <a href="Toiyabe%20National%20Forest">Toiyabe National Forest</a>, which is only accessible a few months a year. The approximately 22 million tons of sulfur ore-containing crushed rock at the mine are responsible for contaminating the Leviathan and Aspen Creek, which join with Mountaineer Creek to form Bryant Creek which ultimately empties into the East Fork of the <a href="Carson%20River">Carson River</a>. These <a href="water%20bodies">water bodies</a> are listed as 303(d) impaired. The site location is <a href="seismic">seismic</a>ally active.
Mining history.
Pre-open pit mining began in 1863 by <a href="Comstock%20Lode">Comstock Lode</a> miners. Between 1863 and 1870, 500 tons of <a href="copper%20sulfate">copper sulfate</a> was removed from two <a href="adit">adit</a>s. This copper sulfate was used for <a href="silver">silver</a> <a href="ore">ore</a> refining. A large sulfur deposit was discovered in one of the adits and the mine was subsequently abandoned. Between 1935 and 1941 <a href="Calpine%20Corporation">Calpine Corporation</a> of <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, which <a href="sublease">sublease</a>d the mine from the Texas Gulf Sulfur Company, conducted subsurface sulfur mining and recovered 5,000 tons of sulfur. Mining was suspended in 1941 due to the hazardous nature of <a href="underground%20mining%20%28hard%20rock%29">mining sulfur underground</a>. In 1945 the Siskon Mining Corporation, acquired the mine.
<a href="Open-pit%20mining">Open-pit mining</a> of sulfur was initiated at the site when <a href="Anaconda%20Copper%20Mining%20Company">Anaconda Copper Mining Company</a> purchased the Leviathan in 1951. The extracted sulfur was used for <a href="copper">copper</a> ore processing at <a href="Anaconda%20Copper%20Mine%20%28Nevada%29">Anaconda Copper Mine (Nevada)</a>. During its excavating operations and Leviathan (1953–1962), Anaconda turned the original mine into a , pit, and removed approximately 500,000 <a href="long%20ton">long ton</a>s of sulfur. During this time period <a href="acid%20mine%20drainage">acid mine drainage</a> (AMD) began contaminating Leviathan Creek. In 1963, Anaconda sold the property to founders of the Alpine Mining Enterprises, Zella N. Mann and William Chris Mann, who was the Alpine County Clerk.
Post-mining clean-up.
Site cleanup began with the 1983-1985 formation of the Leviathan Mine Pollution Abatement Project by the Lahontan Regional Water Quality Control Board (LRWQCB) which was built in an effort to mitigate acid mine drainage. The State of <a href="California">California</a> acquired Leviathan from Alpine Mining Enterprises in 1984, and the <a href="California%20State%20Water%20Resources%20Control%20Board">California State Water Resources Control Board</a> gained jurisdiction over the property. The Leviathan Mine Pollution Abatement Project consisted of building drains beneath the pit to capture contaminated water and making <a href="evaporation%20pond">evaporation pond</a>s, filling and <a href="land%20grading">regrading</a> the pit, and separating uncontaminated <a href="surface%20water">surface water</a> from AMD <a href="groundwater">groundwater</a>. Results of the project include the discovery of unknown <a href="acid">acid</a>ic <a href="spring%20%28hydrosphere%29">springs</a> and accidental AMD discharge directly into Leviathan Creek via a drain line.
In 1997 the <a href="United%20States%20Environmental%20Protection%20Agency">United States Environmental Protection Agency</a> (EPA) became involved in the cleanup of Leviathan Mine at the request of the <a href="Washoe%20Tribe%20of%20Nevada%20and%20California">Washoe Tribe of Nevada and California</a>. The tribe had concerns about overflow from evaporation ponds onto downstream tribal lands and the impacts of AMD on their cultural and <a href="natural%20resource">natural resource</a>s. The EPA Region IX tried unsuccessfully to use a <a href="lime%20%28material%29">lime</a> neutralization treatment of the AMD. In 1998, the Atlantic Richfield Company (<a href="ARCO">ARCO</a>), who purchased Anaconda in 1977, was issued an Administrative Order on Consent (AOC) by the EPA that obligated them to aid in the mitigation of AMD flow into Leviathan creek. However, due to the use of unproven technologies implemented by ARCO Environmental Remediation, L.L.C. and the logistical challenges of getting supplies to the mine this effort had limited success. Then in 1999, a biphasic neutralization water treatment plant was established by the LRWQCB to treat AMD in the evaporation ponds and minimize over flow into Leviathan Creek.
In 1999 the EPA proposed making Leviathan's open-pit sulfur mine a superfund site by adding it to the <a href="National%20Priorities%20List">National Priorities List</a> for hazardous waste sites. In 2000 EPA added the mine to the NPL, and had the written support of the <a href="Washoe%20Tribe">Washoe Tribe</a>, <a href="Alpine%20County%2C%20California">Alpine County, California</a>, the State of <a href="Nevada">Nevada</a>, <a href="Douglas%20County%2C%20Nevada">Douglas County, Nevada</a> and the Carson River Conservancy District. The LRWQCB was issued an Administrative Abatement Action (AAA) in 2000 (which was renewed in 2001, 2002, 2003, 2004, and 2005) by the EPA in order to continue the biphasic treatment, water quality monitoring and other actives. Since 2005, the involvement of the LRWQCB is determined by the EPA Remedial Project Manager for the mine. In 2000, a unilateral administrative order was issued to ARCO, in which the EPA required ARCO to conduct early response actions and develop a long-term response plan for mitigating AMD.
In 1993 the State of California set up a pilot scale one-cell <a href="bioreactor">bioreactor</a> with <a href="manure">manure</a> substrate for AMD treatment at Leviathan Creek Seep. By 1998, researchers from the <a href="University%20of%20Nevada-Reno">University of Nevada-Reno</a> (UNR) installed a two cell bioreactor at Aspen seep. By 2001, the Aspen seep bioreactor treated 2.5 million gallons of ARD. The design evolved over time and in 2003, at the behest of the State of California, ARCO and the UNR researchers developed a <a href="compost">compost</a>-free <a href="sulfate">sulfate</a> reducing bioreactor at Aspen Seep.
Environmental damage.
<a href="Sulfuric%20acid">Sulfuric acid</a> is produced at the open-pit mine when water, such as <a href="rain">rain</a>, <a href="snow">snow</a> melt or <a href="groundwater">groundwater</a>, interacts with the waste rock. This sulfuric acid <a href="leaching%20%28chemistry%29">leaches</a> contaminants from surrounding rock, such as <a href="arsenic">arsenic</a>, <a href="copper">copper</a>, <a href="nickel">nickel</a>, <a href="zinc">zinc</a>, <a href="chromium">chromium</a>, <a href="aluminum">aluminum</a> and <a href="iron">iron</a>. This acid rock drainage ARD, with a low pH, and high concentrations of dissolved sulfate and <a href="metal">metal</a>s, flows into the surrounding <a href="drainage%20basin">watershed</a> and has adverse effects on water quality through deposition of metal-rich precipitates, which cascade through the <a href="ecosystem">ecosystem</a> affecting <a href="algae">algae</a>, <a href="insect">insect</a>, and <a href="fish">fish</a>. The site is <a href="vegetation">unvegetated</a> and is susceptible to <a href="erosion">erosion</a> due to several long steep slopes. The instability resulting from the open-pit mine has resulted in several <a href="landslide">landslide</a>s, with one affecting over .
Human health concerns.
Contact with contaminates from the mine can result in both <a href="cancer">cancer</a>ous and non-cancerous health effects depending on where, when, and how long the exposure occurred. <a href="Arsenic">Arsenic</a> poses the most significant health risk to exposed individuals via contact with contaminated <a href="surface%20water">surface water</a> and <a href="sediment">sediment</a>. Other risks for exposure include eating fish, plants and wild game collected near the mine, inhalation of <a href="dust">dust</a> near the mine, and or eating animals raised near Leviathan. In general, avoiding contact with <a href="mine%20tailings">mine tailings</a>, surface water, and sediments in Leviathan, Aspen, and Bryant creeks, as well as the River Ranch Irrigation channel will reduce contaminate exposure and therefore reduce health risks.
Biphasic neutralization water treatment.
Biphasic neutralization water treatment is a two-step process. Phase I raises the <a href="pH">pH</a> of the outflow to the point that <a href="iron">iron</a> <a href="precipitation%20%28chemistry%29">precipitates</a> out of solution as <a href="ferric%20hydroxide">ferric hydroxide</a> and arsenic co-precipitates with the ferric hydroxide. This <a href="sludge">sludge</a> is then removed and disposed of at an appropriate <a href="hazardous%20waste">hazardous waste</a> facility. In Phase II the pH of the effluent is raised again and additional metals precipitate. Much of this sludge is non-hazardous and is stored at Leviathan. The remaining <a href="wastewater">wastewater</a> can then be discharged into Leviathan Creek.
Compost-free sulfate reducing bioreactor.
The compost-free sulfate reducing <a href="bioreactor">bioreactor</a> employs sulfate-reducing <a href="microbe">microbe</a>s (e.g. <a href="Desulfovibrio">Desulfovibrio</a> sp.) to reduce <a href="sulfate">sulfate</a> to <a href="sulfide">sulfide</a> at pH 4.0 
. However, the ARD at Aspen Seep is too acidic (pH 3.1) and is pretreated with <a href="sodium%20hydroxide">sodium hydroxide</a> solution. <a href="Ethanol">Ethanol</a>, the <a href="carbon">carbon</a> source for the sulfate reducing microbes, is also added to the system (,). The solution is reduced from sulfate to sulfide in Bioreactor No. 1, which is lined with 60-millimeter <a href="high-density%20polyethylene">high-density polyethylene</a> (HDPE) and filled with river rocks, which aid in the flow of <a href="effluent">effluent</a>. The sulfide effluent is passed into Bioreactor No. 2 for additional metal removal. Next, sodium hydroxide is added to the effluent to increase the pH to neutral, and it is sent through two settling ponds (to allow for the settling of metal sulfide precipitates) and a rock-lined <a href="aeration">aeration</a> channel for <a href="degassing">degassing</a> of <a href="hydrogen%20sulfide">hydrogen sulfide</a>. At the end of the aeration channel the effluent is released into Aspen Creek.
